newsitem.title: USA: Societe Generale seen buying almost $1 bln munis.
newsitem.headline: Societe Generale seen buying almost $1 bln munis.

text.p: Societe Generale, a French bank, on Thursday had no comment on rumors that the bank has bought roughly $1 billion of U.S. municipal bonds in recent weeks.

Details were sketchy, and at least one municipal market source described that figure as "a little on the high side." However, municipal market sources said the bank appears to be engaged in an investment strategy that involves derivatives and has purchased "hundreds of millions of dollars of bonds," mainly from New York State municipal bond issuers.
Jeff Stein, a public relations associate at Societe Generale, said the bank had no comment.
"(Societe Generale) have been single handedly a major buyer of municipal bonds," a market source said. "They are running some sort of derivative program, and they are buying a lot of bonds."

Societe Generale has been involved in just about every major deal of late, market sources said. One source said he first became aware of their presence on the recent $934 million Port Authority of New York and New Jersey deal.

"They are carving out large, not-reoffered blocks of bonds supposedly paying through the market in order to secure sizeable positions, and they are running a derivative program," the source said. "...We think that they are doing something against the municipal swap market, the PSA swap market."
Another municipal source also cited derivatives.
"They are certainly not a traditional tax-exempt buyer so it probably is for other rationales," he said.

A New York City official, who declined to be named, said Societe Generale ordered $100 million in two maturities in a recent bond sale by the New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority, closing out both maturities.
"(Societe Generale) did put in that order for water, but we did not know what they did with it," the city official said.
The official added he had heard a recent sale by the Dormitory Authority of the State of New York also closed a few maturities due to orders by big buyers.
